Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Closed and Open Lateral Internal Sphincterotomy for Chronic Anal Fissure

Participants.evidence: Participants were adults with chronic anal fissure.

Intervention.evidence: This study evaluates the efficacy and safety of closed versus open lateral internal sphincterotomy (LIS).

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the efficacy and safety of closed versus open lateral internal sphincterotomy (LIS).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the postoperative healing rate, assessed over a follow-up period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation methods varied, with inconsistent reporting on allocation concealment and blinding.

Blinding.evidence: Randomisation methods varied, with inconsistent reporting on allocation concealment and blinding.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Closed LIS showed higher recurrence rates (RR = 1.73, 95% CI 0.86–3.47) and lower incontinence rates (RR = 0.60, 95% CI 0.37–0.96) compared to open LIS.

Harms.evidence: Adverse events, including postoperative pain and infection, were more frequent in the open LIS group.
